SENT.plain: Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) is infrequent among cerebrovascular diseases
The simultaneous thrombosis involving both cerebral artery and venous sinus is even extremely rare
We reported a 41-year-old woman who presented with acute headache and left hemiparesis due to concomitant arterial ischemic stroke and recurrent CVT
Extensive investigation disclosed acquired protein C and protein S deficiency, iron deficiency anemia (IDA) and cryoglobulinemia
She was treated with intravenous injection of heparin followed by oral anticoagulant therapy
The headache rapidly subsided; however, left hemiparesis persisted over five months
The rare condition of simultaneous thrombosis of cerebral artery and venous sinus may be caused by the synergistic effect of coagulation disorders, IDA and cryoglobulinemia
